Yeh</PersonName>    <PersonNameInverted>Yeh, Emily T.</PersonNameInverted>    <NamesBeforeKey>Emily T.</NamesBeforeKey>    <KeyNames>Yeh</KeyNames>    <BiographicalNote><p>  Emily T. Yeh is Associate Professor of Geography at the University of Colorado at Boulder.</p></BiographicalNote>   </Contributor>   <EditionNumber>1</EditionNumber>   <Language>   <LanguageRole>01</LanguageRole>   <LanguageCode>eng</LanguageCode>  </Language>   <NumberOfPages>344</NumberOfPages>   <Extent>   <ExtentType>00</ExtentType>   <ExtentValue>344</ExtentValue>   <ExtentUnit>03</ExtentUnit>  </Extent>   <NumberOfIllustrations>24</NumberOfIllustrations>   <Illustrations>   <IllustrationType>03</IllustrationType>      <Number>19</Number>  </Illustrations>    <Illustrations>   <IllustrationType>14</IllustrationType>      <Number>3</Number>  </Illustrations>    <Illustrations>   <IllustrationType>11</IllustrationType>      <Number>2</Number>  </Illustrations>    <BASICMainSubject>HIS008000</BASICMainSubject>    <BICMainSubject>HBJF</BICMainSubject>    <Subject>   <SubjectSchemeIdentifier>10</SubjectSchemeIdentifier>   <SubjectCode>POL023000</SubjectCode>  </Subject>  <Subject>   <SubjectSchemeIdentifier>10</SubjectSchemeIdentifier>   <SubjectCode>SOC002010</SubjectCode>  </Subject>   <Subject>   <SubjectSchemeIdentifier>13</SubjectSchemeIdentifier>   <SubjectCode>1FPCT</SubjectCode>  </Subject>   <Subject>   <SubjectSchemeIdentifier>15</SubjectSchemeIdentifier>   <SubjectCode>3JJP</SubjectCode>  </Subject>   <Subject>   <SubjectSchemeIdentifier>24</SubjectSchemeIdentifier>   <SubjectSchemeName>Cornell U.P.  - website hierarchy</SubjectSchemeName>   <SubjectHeadingText>Political Science / Development Studies</SubjectHeadingText>  </Subject>  <Subject>   <SubjectSchemeIdentifier>24</SubjectSchemeIdentifier>   <SubjectSchemeName>Cornell U.P.  - website hierarchy</SubjectSchemeName>   <SubjectHeadingText>Political Science / Foreign Policy</SubjectHeadingText>  </Subject>   <Audience>   <AudienceCodeType>01</AudienceCodeType>   <AudienceCodeValue>01</AudienceCodeValue>  </Audience>   <OtherText>   <TextTypeCode>03</TextTypeCode>   <Text language="eng"><p>The violent protests in Lhasa in 2008 against Chinese rule were met by disbelief and anger on the part of Chinese citizens and state authorities, perplexed by Tibetans' apparent ingratitude for the generous provision of development. In <em>Taming Tibet</em>, Emily T. Yeh examines how Chinese development projects in Tibet served to consolidate state space and power. Drawing on sixteen months of ethnographic fieldwork between 2000 and 2009, Yeh traces how the transformation of the material landscape of Tibet between the 1950s and the first decade of the twenty-first century has often been enacted through the labor of Tibetans themselves. Focusing on Lhasa, Yeh shows how attempts to foster and improve Tibetan livelihoods through the expansion of markets and the subsidized building of new houses, the control over movement and space, and the education of Tibetan desires for development have worked together at different times and how they are experienced in everyday life.</p>  <p>The master narrative of the PRC stresses generosity: the state and Han migrants selflessly provide development to the supposedly backward Tibetans, raising the living standards of the Han's "little brothers." Arguing that development is in this context a form of "indebtedness engineering," Yeh depicts development as a hegemonic project that simultaneously recruits Tibetans to participate in their own marginalization while entrapping them in gratitude to the Chinese state. The resulting transformations of the material landscape advance the project of state territorialization. Exploring the complexity of the Tibetan response to\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdand negotiations with\ufffd\ufffd\ufffddevelopment, <em>Taming Tibet</em> focuses on three key aspects of China\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds modernization: agrarian change, Chinese migration, and urbanization. Yeh presents a wealth of ethnographic data and suggests fresh approaches that illuminate the Tibet Question.</p></Text>  </OtherText>   <OtherText>   <TextTypeCode>02</TextTypeCode>   <Text language="eng">Yeh examines how Chinese development projects in Tibet served to consolidate state space and power.</Text>  </OtherText>   <OtherText>   <TextTypeCode>04</TextTypeCode>   <Text><p>  Preface<br />  Note on Transliterations and Place Names<br />  Abbreviations and Terms<br />  Introduction<br />  A Celebration<br />  1. State Space: Power, Fear, and the State of Exception<br />  Hearing and Forgetting<br />  Part I. Soil<br />  The Aftermath of 2008 (I)<br />  2. Cultivating Control: Nature, Gender, and Memories of Labor in State Incorporation<br />  Part II. Plastic<br />  Lhasa Humor<br />  3. Vectors of Development: Migrants and the Making of "Little Sichuan"<br />  Signs of Lhasa<br />  4. The Micropolitics of Marginalization<br />  Science and Technology Transfer Day<br />  5. Indolence and the Cultural Politics of Development<br />  Part III. Concrete<br />  Michael Jackson as Lhasa<br />  6. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdBuild a Civilized City\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: Making Lhasa Urban<br />  The Aftermath of 2008 (II)<br />  7. Engineering Indebtedness and Image: Comfortable Housing and the New Socialist Countryside<br />  Conclusion<br />  Afterword: Fire<br />  References<br />  Notes<br />  Index</p></Text>  </OtherText>   <OtherText>   <TextTypeCode>08</TextTypeCode>   <Text><p>  "In her masterful new book, <em>Taming Tibet</em>, Emily Yeh discusses the "gift" of development in modern Lhasa in a critical fashion, providing an excellent and informative examination of Chinese development projects over the last sixty plus years. . . . It will be of use to scholars from a variety of fields including ethnicity in China, development studies, and geography, and is also a welcome addition to the Tibetological field."\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTimothy Thurston, <em>Asian Ethnology</em> (winter 2014)</p></Text>   </OtherText>   <OtherText>   <TextTypeCode>08</TextTypeCode>   <Text><p>  "<em>Taming Tibet </em>is a highly original book; no one else is capable of doing the kind of research and analysis that Emily T. Yeh has done among Tibetans in the People's Republic of China. She incorporates an unprecedentedly wide regional and comparative scope of experience, even as the book focuses on the Lhasa valley. This is a timely book, and increasingly so with Tibet's rising geopolitical importance and the recent protests and military crackdown."\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdCharlene E. Makley, Reed College, author of <em>The Violence of Liberation: Gender and Tibetan Buddhist Revival in Post-Mao China</em></p></Text>   </OtherText>   <OtherText>   <TextTypeCode>08</TextTypeCode>   <Text><p>  "Emily T. Yeh's <em>Taming Tibet</em> is one of the best analyses of the contemporary socioeconomics and politics of development of Tibet. The book is based on powerful ethnographic details and strong theoretical analysis and situates the current sociopolitical milieu within the context of the larger issues of the state\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds goal of 'development\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and local subjectivity in transforming the Tibetan landscape. Yeh shows that the issue is not a simple dichotomy between state action and local resistance. The \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgift of development\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd produces an asymmetrical relationship between donor and recipient: the Chinese state\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds desire to make an imprint on the territory while at the same time creating \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinternal others\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdobjects of suspicion.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd <em>Taming Tibet</em> should be required reading for anyone interested in understanding contemporary Tibet and China\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds relations with periphery regions."\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTsering Wangdu Shakya, Canada Research Chair in Religion and Contemporary Society in Asia, University of British Columbia, author of <em>The Dragon in the Land of Snows</em></p></Text>   </OtherText>   <MediaFile>
